description: From Ancient Greek γένεσις (génesis, “origin”). Coined by English biologist William Bateson in 1905 in a letter to zoologist Adam Sedgwick, and first used publicly by Bateson at a lecture to the International Conference on Plant Hybridization in 1906.

entries.meaning: (biology) The branch of biology that deals with the transmission and variation of inherited characteristics, in particular chromosomes and DNA.
(biology) The genetic makeup of a specific individual or species.
